body: @markusthoemmes @rabbah thanks
any update on this?

rebased yet again to master to resolve conflicts.

PG1 2150 üèÉ 

Could we please finally merge once CI approves?
@csantanapr i think it would make sense after all these prs are merged to have a runtimes top level directory (peer with core) and put all the dockerfiles there. thoughts?
PG4 895 üîµ
@mdeuser, made changes as requested, thanks. Anything else?
can you rebase this?
@mhenke1 is doing all this work.

Rebasing as these two are merged now:
#2822 Move swift runtime into it's own repo
#2843 Move python runtime into it's own repo
@cbickel @markusthoemmes ^^ something introduce with recent batching

This is the build https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-openwhisk/builds/289112637

nothing change related to couchdb/store
@rabbah using 301 based on feedback take a look 90106a9571d25e28e0c6973949ea29d89f468b85
PG good üöÄ Playground4 898
PG 1 2154 passed.
PG 1 / 2157 successful with latest changes.
PG2 2177 üîµ
is this change actually sound? it didn't change the invoker code which negotiates with redis - and i suspect we wouldn't see it since we're not activating that part of the code yet.
@mdeuser, @drcariel, @jessealva, @csantanapr, thoughts on the above?

What happens in the case of `wsk action create myaction`, where `myaction` is a file?  i guess this should fail since the runtime is not known.

Same changes for `wsk action update`, which can also be used to create an action ?

In that case, we would have to fail if a kind is not specified and an extension that does not map to a valid runtime is not provided.

Same changes would apply for the update command.
PG 4 / 904 in queue.
@markusthoemmes please attend to this PR.
Per discussion in slack with @jrcrossley3.
Please label as enhancement and assign to me.  I plan to work on this next week.
please assign to me.  I will look at this within the next couple of weeks.
@style95 as you shared on slack, the use of `db_num_read_quorum` and `db_num_write_quorum` I think is discouraged. Can you link the ansible related issue here and is there an update?

@yunspace Apologies for not merging this but we were in the process of moving the runtimes to their own repositories. Can you reopen against this new repo: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-docker/blob/master/sdk/docker/Dockerfile#L13
@ddragosd what is the status of this? I'm not sure from reading the comments.
I'm going to close this - actions should use __OW_API_HOST. If there's a reason this is needed, let's articulate and then reopen.
@bbrowning @style95 It's not clear to me that 2810 is ready. Does it make sense to accept this PR and sort out the clustering separately?
@dubeejw nudge.
@misl we'll need to open this PR against the new java runtime repo https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-java.

Opened https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-java/pull/2.
@csantanapr the doc change in actions.md belongs in this repo still so I'll update this pr accordingly.
Closing in favor of https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2875.
@rabbah How do I run the `WskBasicUsageTests.scala` easily and isolated?
@alexkli, locally you can run `./gradlew tests:test -Dtest.single=WskBasicUsageTests` from the OpenWhisk root directory.

Ah, but that gives this error (I think I saw it before when trying to run tests):

```
* Where:
Build file '/Users/alex/Work/code/openwhisk/incubator-openwhisk/tests/build.gradle' line: 74

* What went wrong:
Execution failed for task ':tests:createKeystore'.
> java.io.FileNotFoundException: /Users/alex/Work/code/openwhisk/incubator-openwhisk/whisk.properties (No such file or directory)
```

Do I need to run a full local OpenWhisk and have the connection details in the `whisk.properties` before being able to run the tests?
@alexkli, you do need a full OpenWhisk deployment setup locally.

@dubeejw Thanks. I have been using [devtools docker-compose](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-devtools/tree/master/docker-compose), I was told that's easiest to setup (and it works fine). How do I get the `whisk.properties` file for it? What needs to go into it?

In the meantime I found `tools/build/redo props` which says it will `build whisk.properties file (required for tests)`. Had to install ansible using `brew install ansible` (which installed a lot of dependencies...).

However running `tools/build/redo props` does not create a `whisk.properties`, it outputs:
```
ansible-playbook -i environments/docker-machine properties.yml
 [WARNING]: Unable to parse /Users/alex/Work/code/openwhisk/incubator-openwhisk/ansible/environments/docker-machine as an inventory source

 [WARNING]: No inventory was parsed, only implicit localhost is available

 [WARNING]: Could not match supplied host pattern, ignoring: all

 [WARNING]: provided hosts list is empty, only localhost is available
...
skipping: no hosts matched
```

AFAICS, the wsk cli tests don't (all?) require a server? Is there no way to run them without?

While I have to wait for help with getting the tests to run, I had a look at `WskBasicUsageTests.scala`.

It seems there is not any positive test for `-P`, only failure tests if no filename is given or if it's an empty file. I feel like I am not familiar enough with scala and the code base here to know how to add such a positive test. Any guidance would be helpful.

@rabbah, @csantanapr, I think it might be possible to use the work here to provide a Scala OpenWhisk client at some point in the future. I think it could fit nicely with the js, swift, go, and python clients.
PG 4 / 906 running.
Is this still planned?
Yes we should do this. Hasn‚Äôt been a priority though with a lot of work on performance and scale out.  There are some nuanced though that need to be worked out.
Carlos when the runtime pr is merged shall I bump the pinned version for the base image in this pr?

@rabbah @jthomas agree. We have been experiencing name collisions with wskdeploy tests as devs copy triggers and rules (and do not change their) names from one test file to another and the results can be quite frustrating as we automate.

Good point @mrutkows. I have the same issue in The Serverless Framework. 
https://github.com/serverless/serverless-openwhisk/issues/29

One way to support this is by pulling images from the private registry to a whisk managed registry at action create time. This would avoid some the challenges around key management for docker login. In general I think this is a good approach for docker actions as it will make it easier for vetting images; but not without its demerits.

@alexkli, check here for positive `-P` tests.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/whisk/core/cli/test/WskBasicUsageTests.scala#L193

https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/whisk/core/cli/test/WskBasicUsageTests.scala#L920

https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/whisk/core/cli/test/WskBasicUsageTests.scala#L920

in scenario 2, the CLI would need to complete the file extension based on the kind flag in order to find the correct local file, right? 

Im a bit confused by the 3rd scenario, would the extension need to match the kind? what happens if they do not match?
@alexkli, I'm not familiar with the devtools project. Perhaps @rabbah has some suggestions.

Try: wskdev setup props
If you have not run ansible before the hosts file may not exist and the error suggests this (i guess we have a missing dependency).

Scenario 2 and 3 are essentially the same. If a kind is not specified, we try to figure out the kind by checking the file extension. If a kind is not specified we need to error if the extension is not present or unknown. When a kind is specified we will always use that and forego checking the file extension. We currently do this today, and it would be applied to the scenarios above.

IMO, the CLI should be careful in not inferring too much from too little in CRUD operations... and if assumptions or inferences are made, the user needs to be informed/warned of this additional behaviors.  

Entity naming and Namespacing is becoming more and more important with Compositions so making these assumptions could cause unintended consequences for user/customers composing solutions with hundreds of actions.

"Hard to misuse":
https://swaggerhub.com/blog/api-design/api-design-best-practices/

`wskdev setup props` fails similar to `tools/build/redo props`, as they seem to run the same and expect a running local ansible based OpenWhisk.

However, after some fiddling around, I was able to successfully run at least the WskBasicUsageTests

    ./gradlew tests:test -Dtest.single=WskBasicUsageTests

against my local OpenWhisk from the [docker-compose setup](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-devtools/tree/master/docker-compose) using this minimal `whisk.properties` file in the root of the checkout:

```properties
openwhisk.home=$OPENWHISK_CHECKOUT_DIR

testing.auth=$USER_HOME/tmp/openwhisk/src/ansible/files/auth.guest
whisk.ssl.cert=$USER_HOME/tmp/openwhisk/apigateway/ssl/openwhisk-server-cert.pem

edge.host=$LOCAL_IP:443
whisk.api.host.proto=https
whisk.api.host.name=$LOCAL_IP
whisk.api.host.port=443

vcap.services.file=
use.cli.download=false
```

Replace the variables in there:
* `$OPENWHISK_CHECKOUT_DIR`: absolute path to the openwhisk git checkout
* `$USER_HOME`: absolute path to your user home (e.g. `/Users/alex`), tilde `~` does not work
* `$LOCAL_IP`: local IP (`localhost` might work too)
I agree with @mrutkows , I think it's important to inform the user that these assumptions are being made in real time.
Less magic FTW and clarity. What's the point of saving the user from `.js` or `.py` it's not that many more characters and potentially confusing. Maybe I missed the rationale here.

No API changes here. This is a usability issue to allow the user to type less information when creating/update an action. Ie, not having to provide an action name. The CLI will continue to work as it does today when creating/updating actions even with the changes mentioned above.

To be more clear, here are some more examples.

Say the user wants to create an action that has the same name as his or her filename. Instead of the user having to type duplicate information, we only need the filename to be provided. Ex:
```
$ wsk action create myActionName.js
ok: created action myActionName
```

The CLI would still work as it does today allowing a filename and an action name if the user wants the action name to differ from the filename:
```
$ wsk action create myAction myActionName.js
ok: created action myAction
```

I get that it's client only - I'm just not sure I like the automatic inference here. Note that the CLI change is actually going to change behavior (1 is an error today, and will work after these changes).

I can see the value in the 1st use case. Maybe the scope should be limited to this?

2  is where I see more user complications 
( For example: different files with the same name but different extensions  etc..)

3 still doesn't make sense to me, but I am not sure how it works in it's current state TBH.

> I can see the value in the 1st use case. Maybe the scope should be limited to this?

yeah maybe... but also feel that if you're doing anything serious you're going to use a deployment framework like `wskdeploy` or you're writing your own scripts. I could be convinced to buy into 1.

```bash
wsk action create foo.zip --kind nodejs:6
```

do you want that to work? I think that's maybe a use of 3.

@dubeejw @rabbah Thanks for the help. Once I got the tests running and the project in IntelliJ with Scala support, it was fairly straightforward.

PR updated with
* tests for `-P -` option for: action/package/trigger create, and action invoke with file and stdin cases
* updated the i18n json file

@rabbah Let me explain the issues here.

In this pr, `apache/couchdb` is being used.
That image does not support environment variables for `n`, `q`, `r`, `w`, and that's the reason why I initially created this PR(apache/couchdb-docker#32).

And I got comment from couchdb community that,

1. `n` will be automatically configured while setting up cluster.
2.  `q` only matters when creating database and can be specified `?q=1` parameter.
3. Explicit `r` and `w` configurations are deprecated, instead couchdb will use half of the number of replicas for those two values.
(These can also be specified via parameter in API) 
4. After setting up cluster, cluster configurations will be stored in `/opt/couchdb/etc/local.d`, so couchdb community highly recommend to use volume mapping of that directory.

In short, we don't need those configurations any more.
Instead, we need to add `q` param when creating a database.

I will update the code accordingly.

One question is, would it be required to add volume mapping for configuration directory as well?
For this, we need to keep configuration directory and files in OW repo such as `etc/default.ini` `etc/default.d/*.ini` `etc/local.d` because there will be no default configuration when volume is mapped.
Will go for 6.11.4 new runtime image being updated here https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-nodejs

Scenario two and three are just to keep in sync with the same type functionality that currently works with `--kind`. Currently the filename extension is disregarded if a kind is specified.

I think zip files would fall under the third scenario. 

@drcariel, good point above same filenames with different extensions. 

For me at least, I find that I create a lot of different actions to test the backend manually. Having to type an action name all the time just seems redundant when I name the file appropriately.

@rabbah 
Code is updated accordingly.
Regarding `q` value, default is `8`.
I think it would be a good starting point, how do you think?

@dubeejw @rabbah as long as the CLI (API) provide the "clean contract" to the users... I agree with Rodric that the CLI should provide plain/straightforward functionality with known (contracted) results and higher-order tooling should provide the interaction/fuzzy logic.  

If the CLI is performing logic based upon some inference of user intent, then that provides less assurance to tooling built on top.  I would rather have success/fail from the CLI with clear return codes and not have any other extended logic where possible.
@jpkessle, thanks for the feedback!
@csantanapr, I made updates based on comments.

Investigating this a bit - crudely for now: 

bringing up an invoker with no controllers, the number of stem cells is what's expected: 2.
bringing up the controller thereafter leads to two more stem cells.
disabling the health protocol in the controller and bringing that version up, stem cell count remains steady at 2.

this suggests some accounting is initially wrong or the health actions are consuming the stem cells.

looking at https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/d86c415a1d9a4eaa2061eac3a6ce99f24ba390f9/core/invoker/src/main/scala/whisk/core/containerpool/ContainerPool.scala#L151-L170

the health actions are actually using some of the stems cells, which then causes more pre warm containers to be spawned.
@csantanapr @jasonpet is this pr still valid?
@dubeejw can you address the last suggestions?

The SDK is now built externally and the edge router just points to a release. The same could be done for the CLI. This would simplify this PR significantly. Hence I am inclined to close this PR in its current state.

FYI @dgrove-oss
@gbdrt can you update the npm version and open the pr against the new repo https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-nodejs

Trying to understand the need for this - did you consider changing the manifest to inform the invoker of locally available images it should just use directly e.g., https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all#L94
Not needed anymore we found a different solution using environment variable from the action to find API host for github to callback whisk for webhooks

You can push your docker action to dockerhub  and then specify the image $user/myimage

You can also push to another registry and configure access to your local environment 

If you don't want skip the pull all together then what @rabbah suggested should work

build your local image and tag it with the default prefix whisk
docker build . -t whisk/myblackbox 

Then in the manifest add "myblackbox" as a blackbox image 
If this doesn't work then we have a bug :-) and should fix
Yep that's the idea once the CLI is out of the core repo to its own repo then edge would just point to the built binaries on the github release page

The need is local development with OpenWhisk and testing docker images (action containers) without having to publish them. It‚Äôs an unnecessary step to push and pull the (possibly large) image over the network after each change, and because it might be a proprietary image and setting up a private registry is extra work.

The suggestion with the manifest are also extra work and can‚Äôt be configured at runtime, i.e. if you have a new image or change its name, you‚Äôd have to redeploy the local OpenWhisk AFAIU.

@csantanapr I try the whisk/ prefix.

Another production problem I could see: if docker pull fails because of a temporary network error, the entire (cold) invocation will fail, even though the latest image is present locally, because it _always_ does docker pull first from what I see.

I think adding a check for tags having the assumption that if image name contains a :tag the invoker can just do the docker CLI run if image is not already locally docker CLI will download and cache skipping the download on subsequent runs
The corner case is when the tag is not specified or using latest we delegate the checking to compare to the docker CLI pull to do it

when the action gets updated is our indication to do the checking to see if there is a latest image available and doing the docker pull is the route to go with currently, failing on the pull and fallback to use an old image might not be desired in some cases

Today Using manifest to specify set of local images should be easy
You can specify multiple in advanced like 
Test1
Test2
Test3
Test4

Only the invoker needs to be redeploy if modifying that list  I believe 

My proposal on using tag then the action can be created with image tag making the pull to be skipped but this is a proposal not implented currently
For local dev, tagging the image as whisk/ should suffice.
Make more sense for none blocking invocations and since we are sure container didn't start we keep close to our at most once

Yep I agree prefix whisk I think you meant, not tag 
Yeah should be trivial if not clear we can provide example
